results.title: Danny's egg (K)
results.creator_credit: David Haythornthwaite, Michael Midlam and PBL Productions
results.brief_description: The story of Danny, a young boy living in an Australian country town, who discovers an emu’s egg and sets about ensuring that it hatches. Danny is thwarted by the school michief-maker but manages to incubate the egg. Provides a delightful look at the diverse skills required of the country teacher and the lifestyle of country schoolchildren. Written by David Haythornthwaite from a story by Jim Badger. Cast includes Ken Talbot as Danny. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Danny's Egg (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Danny rescues an emu’s egg from a marauding goanna. His ingenuity and tenacity in managing to incubate and finally hatch the egg in the face of opposition win him respect and admiration. It’s a heart-warming, contemporary story with likeable characters who offer a glimpse of life in a country town. Award-winning drama based on a true story by Jim Badger.

results.title: Dangerous game (Ferrara)
results.creator_credit: Abel Ferrara, Mary Kane and Maverick
results.brief_description: ‘Dangerous Game’ is a film about film. Eddie Israel (Keitel) is a director on a shoot in L.A.. His film depicts the extreme emotions and escalating violence of a married couple at a destructive crossroad and departure point in their relationship. Reality blurs when the actors Sarah Jenning (played by Madonna) and Francis Burns (James Russo) increasingly begin to live the lives of their characters, as the demands of their roles intensify, corrupting their own sensibilities. A fissure in Israel’s middleclass suburban N.Y. life is opened and the rot sets in when he allows the film to become the vehicle for his own frustrations. As much about film as being one, ‘Dangerous Game’ borrows inspiration from Cassavettes and turns the film around to reflect itself. Although the film focuses on Israel’s desire to see the actors plumb the depths of the emotion in their roles, ‘Dangerous Game’ becomes more of a comment on what is lost during the process. This is supported by a sequence in the film from Blank’s documentary ‘Burden of Dreams’, featuring an interview with Werner Herzog on shoot for ‘Fitzcarraldo’.

results.title: Dangerous creatures (PC)
results.brief_description: Welcome to the interactive world of dangerous creatures! You’ll be amazed as you discover the truth - and the extraordinary myths - about these intriguing creatures. ‘Dangerous creatures’ comes with an overview movie that teaches you the basics of using the program. The first time you start the program, you’ll be given the opportunity to see the overview. You can also choose to see the overview whenever you like. SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: Multimedia PC that includes a 386SX or higher, at least 4MB of RAM, 2.5MB of available hard disk space, CD-ROM drive, audio board and VGA or VGA+. MS DOS and Microsoft Windows operating system version 3.1 or later.

results.title: Dancing in the moonlight
results.creator_credit: Ned Lander, Trevor Graham, Sharon Connolly, Townsville Aboriginal & Islander Media Association and Yarra Bank Films
results.brief_description: Dancing in the Moonlight tells the story of the Fifth Festival of Pacific Arts held in Townsville in August 1988. Amid celebration and performance, indigenous Pacific peoples shared and debated ideas and and concerns which inform life in the region today. Many South Pacific peoples are struggling to achieve the right to self-determination, to reclaim lands lost to the colonisers, fisheries invaded by big business and peaceful societies threatened by superpower deployment of nuclear weapons throughout their ocean. “Dancing in the Moonlight” is testament to their struggle to maintain their own languages and culture in the face of political, economic and cultural imperialism.

results.title: Dance: Videos of Australian dancers and choreographers
results.brief_description: Famous Australian dancers and choreographers give lively and engaging interviews of their fascinating lives in the world of dance. Discover what it was like to be a dancer or choreographer in Australia during the past fifty years.

results.title: Dance on a May Day
results.creator_credit: John G. Avildsen and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Focuses on professional dancer Jacques d’Amboise, who founded the National Dance Institute for the purpose of introducing dance to boys. Observes d’Amboise and his students in practice sessions, as well as in performance at New York’s Lincoln Center.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John G. Avildsen and Learning Corporation of America

results.title: Dance of death
results.brief_description: A young girl, Sally Roberts, transfixed by the violence portrayed on TV enthusiastically tunes into the ‘Dance of Death’, a TV game show. The ‘Dance of Death’ hosted by ‘The Smiling Scull’ is a show where the willing contestants compete to kill themselves in the most imaginative way possible. Turning back on TV for it’s content the animation uses TV in this black comedy to critique the role of TV and effect it has on shaping our culture - with a focus on how too much violence desensitises it’s audience allowing the audience to consent to their own victimisation. (Award: Best non-feature animation 1983 AFI Awards)

results.title: Dance in the primary school (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Derek Monk, Freelance Directors and Schools Council
results.brief_description: Shows what can be achieved with children of different ages and varying ability and experience. Illustrates the framework of a lesson; some stimuli used to initiate movement - voice, percussion, pictures; how several teachers, drawing on their own resources enrich the children’s experience; ways to extend children in the main part of the lesson; development of a simple group dance.

results.title: Dance Dans Tanz Danse
results.brief_description: Founded in 1926 by Marie Rambert, Rambert Dance Company is one of dance’s most consistently innovative and imaginative companies. Here are three modern dances by the company featuring music by Bill Withers. The three are: “Lonely Town, Lonely Street” a jazz ballet which conveys a picture of lonely people in a large city; “Intimate Pages” using Janacek’s Second String Quartet; and “Sergeant Early’s Dream” recalling the folklore of the old world with British, Irish and American folk songs. Rated: G
